statement.tex: \text{Find the equation of all lines having} \\ \text{slope 2 which are tangent to the curve} \\ \qquad y = \dfrac{1}{x-3}, x\neq 3.

step.context: \text{Which of the following correctly gives} \\ \text{the slope of the tangent at a point (x,y)?}

step.tex: \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= 2 \implies -\dfrac{1}{(x-3)^2} = 2 \\ \implies (x-3)^2&\lt 0 \end{align} \\ \text{This is not possible for any }x\in\mathbb{R}. \\ \text{Hence, no tangent with slope = 2 } \\ \text{can exist for }y=\dfrac{1}{x-3}, x\neq 3.
